column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: Cochlear's report included Cochlear AG, Cochlear Canada Inc., and Cochlear Taiwan Ltd.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: Cochlear's report covers its performance from 1 July 2022 to 30 June 2023.
Cochlear's sustainability data was internally reviewed and not submitted to external assurance. The executive team approves the content of the report.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: Cochlear has been the global leader in implantable hearing solutions for over 40 years, providing a range of implants and sound processor upgrades that deliver a lifetime of hearing outcomes.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: Before any potential candidate is appointed as a senior executive or director or recommended to shareholders as a candidate for election as a director, appropriate background checks are performed, including the person's criminal record, bankruptcy history, character, experience and education. Cochlear provides shareholders with all information relevant to deciding whether to elect or re-elect a director.
column20: Background check, director, senior executive

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Ms Alison Deans is the chair of Cochlear's Board.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column13: Cochlear's risk framework enables it to understand and adapt to the strategic challenges of its operating environment. Cochlear's risk governance diagram outlines Cochlear's risk governance framework and the key responsibilities of the Board, the Executive team, Internal Audit and the business units, incorporating the three lines model for managing risk. Cochlear uses it to manage material risk types, including financial, non-financial and strategic risks.
column20: Risk framework, strategic challenge, operating environment

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: The purpose of the Cochlear Share Ownership Policy is to ensure the appropriate alignment of the interests of Cochlear's executives with the financial interests of Cochlear's shareholders. The guidelines aim to create a share-ownership focus and culture and build long-term commitment to the Company by providing direction to KMP regarding minimum share ownership levels.
column20: Share Ownership Policy, financial interest, share-ownership focus

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column13: New non-executive directors are provided with an induction program. The program includes providing a briefing pack, online and face-to-face product training, one-on-one meetings with the CEO, president, and executive team and visits to key functional areas. On an ongoing basis, directors are provided with papers, presentations, and briefings on matters that may affect Cochlear's business or operations.
column20: Induction program, briefing pack, product training

column13: The Board reviews the interests notified by directors regularly and formally assesses director independence annually. The Board has determined that each director other than the CEO and president was independent throughout the reporting period.
column20: Interest, independence, director

column13: Cochlear's Whistleblower Protection Policy empowers Eligible Protected Persons Ã¢ÂÂ including current and former suppliers and employees of suppliers Ã¢ÂÂ to report any suspected or actual misconduct concerning Cochlear, including any suspected instances of modern slavery. The Whistleblower Protection Policy is available on Cochlear's website in English and other languages relevant to its global business.
column20: Whistleblower Protection Policy, Eligible Protected Person, misconduct

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column13: The Cochlear Board Skills Matrix sets out the mix of skills the Board currently has in its membership. In selecting potential new directors, the Nomination Committee uses the Matrix to assess the needs of the Board and its current composition to ensure a range of skills and experience required to enable the Board to fulfil its responsibilities.
column20: Board Skills Matrix, new director, skill, experience

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: The Chair evaluated the performance of individual directors concerning the reporting period by a process agreed upon with the members of the Nomination Committee. The performance of the Board is independently reviewed regularly, with the most recent review being undertaken between April and June 2022. This review also included the performance of the Chair. The review's key findings were discussed at the following Nomination Committee meeting.
column20: Performance, Director, Nomination Committee

column7: Cochlear's executive remuneration strategy is designed to attract, motivate, and retain a highly qualified and experienced group of executives employed across diverse geographies.

column13: All deferred STI and LTI plan participants are subject to the Clawback Policy. The policy enables the Board to claw back remuneration outcomes in the event of material non-compliance with any financial reporting requirement, misconduct, or inappropriate behaviour post-employment in cases where the Board has exercised its discretion to allow equity retention following employment termination.
column20: Clawback Policy, remuneration, material non-compliance

column7: Cochlear's Non-Executive Directors are paid from an aggregate annual fee pool of $3,500,000.

"Over the past year, we have made great progress in our mission to help more people to hear. Our strong financial and operational results reflect our unwavering dedication to our customers and our disciplined approach to execution. "

column13: In FY23, Cochlear updated its Global Code of Conduct, maintaining the high standard of conduct, business ethics, and integrity required of its people worldwide to drive its business forward. Cochlear conducted annual mandatory training on the Global Code of Conduct for all staff globally.
column20: Mandatory training, Global Code of Conduct, business ethics

column13: Should Cochlear identify any practices of concern at a supplier, it will work with the relevant supplier to provide support and take appropriate measures to ensure that the supplier's practices are aligned with Cochlear's standards and expectations as set out in the Supplier Code of Conduct. Suppliers are required under the Supplier Code of Conduct to have a robust corrective action process to drive improvement in safety, sustainability, labour standards and ethical trading principles.
column20: Supplier Code of Conduct, supplier, ethical trading principle

column13: Cochlear undertakes an annual ESG review of its supply chains and procurement activities to ensure appropriate ESG risk screening and any remedial actions are being undertaken. This annual review also includes assessing the ongoing effectiveness of Cochlear's current processes in identifying and addressing modern slavery and other ESG risks.
column20: ESG review, supply chain, procurement activity

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: The Cochlear Whistleblower Service is an externally operated confidential service, available anywhere in the world, at any time through which Eligible Protected Persons, including current and former suppliers and employees of suppliers, can anonymously (subject to local laws and regulations) submit reports of any breach of law, regulation or Cochlear policy or procedure including for any breaches of Cochlear's Global Code of Conduct and the Supplier Code of Conduct.
column20: Cochlear Whistleblower Service, Eligible Protected Person, Code of Conduct

column13: The ASX Listing Rules require Cochlear to have a trading policy that applies to its Key Management Personnel (KMP). This is in addition to the insider trading prohibitions of the Corporations Act, which apply to all of Cochlear's directors, officers and employees (and their associates). The Trading Policy is an important tool in managing the risks associated with dealings in securities.
column20: Trading Policy, Key Management Personnel, insider trading

column7: As a signatory to the voluntary Business Council of Australia Supplier Code, Cochlear aims to pay eligible Australian small businesses within 30 days of receiving correct invoices and products.

column13: Cochlear Family is Cochlear's recipient awareness and education membership program. It provides information about the hearing journey and support for recipients, their families, and carers living with hearing implant technology. Proactive communications and hosted events aim to help upskill recipients and their carers to live more confidently with hearing technology.
column20: Cochlear Family, education membership program, implant technology

column13: Cochlear's communication to shareholders is based on openness and honesty. These principles are set out in the Shareholder Communications Policy.
column20: Shareholder Communications Policy, shareholder, openness, honesty

column7: Cochlear did not specifically disclose this information.

column13: Cochlear's materiality assessment, conducted in 2022, was informed by a market scan of key sustainability trends, benchmarking against industry peers and stakeholder engagement. This year, Cochlear focused on better understanding the perspective of implant recipients by undertaking surveys in several key markets.
column20: Materiality assessment, market scan, key sustainability trend

column7: Cochlear's material topics are data privacy, employee value proposition, and research and innovation.

column13: Cochlear's NucleusÃÂ® SmartNav System supports surgeons in optimising electrode placement during cochlear implant surgery. It provides real-time, actionable intraoperative insights that increase confidence in device placement to help surgeons optimise outcomes and postoperative clinical performance.
column20: Nucleus SmartNav System, surgeon, electrode placement
